newsitem.title: GERMANY: Tietmeyer reaffirms support for a stable euro.
newsitem.headline: Tietmeyer reaffirms support for a stable euro.

text.p: Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer on Friday reaffirmed his long-standing support for the planned single European currency to be stable, saying his comments on the euro were not "a German stability fetish".
"Only a strong and stable euro can bring Europe forward," Tietmeyer said in the text of a speech due for delivery in Osnabrueck.

Tietmeyer warned a weak euro, which is set to begin in January 1999 as outlined in the Maastricht Treaty, "could in the long-term easily lead to conflicts both within countries themselves and also among countries".

"The euro, in extent of its future stability, thus influences not only the purely economic prospects for grwoth, investment and employment. In a wider sense, the euro also affets which way European societies will develop," he said.
A copy of Tietmeyer's speech to the German Association of Foundations was made available under embargo by the Bundesbank.
Tietmeyer said a stable euro would promote a stronger, liberal and free-market oriented Europe, a statement he has often made in calling for the new currency to be very stable.
On the other hand, Tietmeyer said, "A weak euro would easily lead to a vicious circle of civic discouragement, excessive stress on governments and damaging struggles about the allocation of wealth."
